name: Innate
headline: Teachable general-purpose robots
description: Innate is developing innately intelligent teachable general-purpose robots. Our platforms are simple, accessible, so as to lower the barrier to entry into robotics for everyone.
tags: industry:generative-ai; industry:hard-tech; industry:robotics; industry:consumer; industry:ai-assistant; location:san-francisco-bay-area

founders.name: Axel Peytavin, Founder
founders.description: Building robots that feel alive @Innate. Former research engineer @Stanford HCI @The Ocean Cleanup

founders.name: Vignesh Anand, Founder
founders.description: Former Stanford robotics graduate student. Former flight sciences intern at Archer. Also built high-powered rockets and underwater robots. Currently building the future of embodied AI with Innate

Innate is developing teachable home robots for builders. Our robots act entirely autonomously, and can be taught new behaviors in under 30 minutes. Our first units are shipping in Winter 2025.

generated_description:
**Company Overview: Innate**

Founded in 2024 and based in Palo Alto, Innate is on a mission to make robotics accessible and intuitive. As part of the Y Combinator Batch F24, the company is focused on developing general-purpose robots that anyone can teach and use effectively. The core idea is simple: lower the barrier to entry in robotics, making it available for builders of all backgrounds.

Innate is particularly excited about its first robot, Maurice. This compact device embodies the company‚Äôs visionary approach‚Äîit's not just a product; it's a platform for creativity. Maurice is designed for builders, capable of understanding and executing tasks based on user input in as little as 30 minutes. Imagine teaching your robot to pick up trash or monitor your home for intruders, all done easily and intuitively.

The team, currently just two strong, is led by Nicolas Dessaigne as their Group Partner. They are diving into the realms of generative AI and hard tech, weaving together the nuances of robotics, AI assistants, and consumer interactions. This multidisciplinary approach is evident in Maurice's design, which uses complex learning algorithms to adapt and respond in real-time to its environment, ensuring a blend of autonomy and user control.

### What's Next?

Innate's first units are slated for shipping in Winter 2025, a timeline that fuels the anticipation among potential users. They emphasize community engagement, inviting interested individuals to join their [Discord](https://innate.bot/<https:/discord.com/invite/KtkyT97kc7>) channel. 

Their website (https://innate.bot) showcases not only the technology and capabilities of Maurice but also serves as a hub for documentation and user inquiries. They are ready to welcome preorders and are engaging with users, offering a glimpse into the future of household robotics.

In essence, Innate isn‚Äôt just building robots; they‚Äôre crafting new opportunities for interaction and creativity in our daily lives. As they continue to develop this innovative technology, they stand poised to make a significant impact on the future of home automation and robotics.
